This work investigates the kinetics of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst based on a dual-site Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. Such studies on reaction kinetics and mechanism using In2O3 catalyst, which possesses high activity, selectivity and stability are limited. Thirteen sets of experimental data at steady-state using In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst with varying temperature (200–300 °C), pressure (1–50 bars), gas hourly space velocity (5,893 hr−1 −58,938 hr−1) were analysed. The experimental data were modelled to determine the rate-determining step and the rate expression using the Most-Abundant Reaction Intermediate (MARI) analysis. The reaction mechanism for this catalyst was proposed based on a reported DFT study on In2O3. An optimisation procedure was performed to identify new kinetic parameters using MATLAB-based code with nonlinear regression analysis. A comparison of estimated kinetic parameters was made with reported values. The derived kinetic model can be applied for reactor modelling in the future for scaling up purposes. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol synthesis Indium oxide Rate-determining step Kinetic model Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentration has increased by more than 30% since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, with the current concentration at the atmospheric level hitting a record of 417 ppm in July 2021, according to NASA [1]. With the rapid industrialisation and increasing demand for energy, the addition of CO2 as a greenhouse gas into the environment could not be avoided. Thus, to mitigate global warming, one of the approaches available is carbon dioxide capture and utilisation (CCU). CCU involves capturing CO2 from point sources or air, which is used as feedstock to produce various types of chemicals, plastic, or fuels [2]. Using CO2 represents a realistic solution to solving both the CO2 emissions and the energy crisis [3]. Researchers are currently investigating utilising CO2 as a feedstock to synthesise chemical products such as dimethyl ether (DME), dimethyl carbonate (DMC), formic acid, polymers, and methanol. Four CCU processes have been successfully commercialised, such as urea, salicylic acid, cyclic carbonate and polyols. In CCU, three significant reactions utilise CO2 for fuel production. These are the hydrogenation reactions to methanol and methane and the reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide [4]. Comparing the 2 CO2 hydrogenation reactions, methanol production is more commercially attractive as only 3 moles of H2 gas are required to react with 1 mol of CO2. In contrast, methane synthesis requires an extra mole of H2 gas. Furthermore, there is a significant demand for methanol in the industry attributed to its usage as an energy storage medium, a fuel, and a primary chemical [5]. The demand for methanol is expected to exceed 10 million tons per year in 2023, and it will outgrow the production capacity [6]. A Nobel-prize-winning chemist, George Olah, promoted the “Methanol Economy” concept over the past decade, using methanol as a fuel and gasoline additive [5]. His idea of a methanol economy was exemplified in the first commercial renewable methanol production plant built in Iceland by Carbon Recycling International [4]. The recycling of CO2 through chemical reduction with renewable hydrogen to produce methanol has attracted more interest because it offers a viable way to release humankind from the dependence on depleting fossil fuels while at the same time utilising and storing all sources of energy (renewable and atomic) [5]. This work aims to study the production of methanol via catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 with a particular focus on the kinetic modelling of the process and the determination of the reaction mechanism. Many studies have been carried out on the reaction of catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to synthesise methanol. Two competitive reactions co-occur when methanol is produced only by the hydrogenation of pure CO2. These are methanol synthesis (Eq. 1) and the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) (Eq. 2). Conventionally, methanol is produced on a commercial CuO-ZnO/ Al2O3 (CZA) catalyst from syngas composition of (H2 – CO2)/ (CO + CO2) with a molar ratio of 2, where CO2 is not the only source of carbon. This involved the third reaction to synthesize methanol, as shown in Eq. 3. Eq. 1 and Eq. 3 correspond to the production of methanol which is exothermic and thermodynamically less favourable. To maximise the conversion of CO2, a trade-off temperature condition is required [7]. However, at higher temperatures, the exothermic methanol formation reaction (Eq. 1) must compete with the endothermic RWGS reaction (Eq. 2). Since high temperature favours the forward reaction of endothermic RWGS, more CO and water will be formed as by-products instead of methanol, hence lowering the selectivity of methanol. (1) CO 2 + 3 H 2 ↔ CH 3 OH + H 2 O ( ∆ H = − 49.5 kJ / mol ) (2) CO 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O ( ∆ H = 41.2 kJ / mol ) (3) CO + 2 H 2 ↔ CH 3 OH ( ∆ H = − 90.8 kJ / mol ) At this stage, methanol is still being produced using the commercial CZA catalyst via a conventional route (syngas feedstock) at a moderate temperature of 200–300 °C and high pressure of 50–100 bar condition. Based on the reported performance of Cu and Pd-based catalysts in the literature, the reactions usually undergo CO2 hydrogenation with a reaction temperature below 300 °C [8]. It is difficult for these catalysts to keep up with the desirable high selectivity of methanol at temperatures higher than 300 °C. This is because Copper Oxide (CuO) and Palladium (Pd) have a Hüttig temperature of 207 °C and 275 °C, respectively [9]. The sintering rates of CuO and Pd are significantly higher than the Huttig temperature. Besides, the high temperature tends to shift the reaction to RWGS. During the hydrogenation process, steam is formed as the by-product, and it is found to inhibit the reaction rate and causes sintering of the catalyst [10], a common issue faced when using the commercial CZA catalyst. The catalysts used in the industry generally have a lifetime of 2–4 years [6]. Catalysts’ low stability characteristics are due to deactivation problems, which is undesirable for the industry. Methanol plants usually counteract the deactivations of catalysts by varying the operating pressure and temperature and introducing recycle flow to maintain productivity. This action meanwhile, still put stress on energy consumption [6]. This is not feasible during large-scale operations as the cost will be high to sustain the low stability of the catalyst and the extensive energy usage. Besides, the kinetic inhibition effect also occurs because of the high coverage of adsorbates on the CZA catalyst when a high concentration of CO2 feedstock is used. Hence, to motivate the utilisation of direct CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the CZA catalyst’s limitations must be overcome by searching for efficient catalysts with favourable kinetics at high concentrations of CO2 [11]. Indium oxide (In2O3) has recently been discovered as a breakthrough catalyst with superior catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation [12]. From the density functional theory (DFT) studies of CO2 activation over Al2O3, Ga2O3, and In2O3, the latter was discovered to possess high activity towards adsorption and activation of CO2 [13]. In previous work, no catalysts were reported in the literature with high activity for CO2 hydrogenation using a single oxide catalyst [12]. Besides that, the In2O3-based catalyst has shown 100% selectivity to methanol at all temperatures tested, significantly better than the CZA catalyst, which only has a maximum of 47% [14]. Furthermore, in the work of Martin et al. [14], they have discovered remarkable stability for 1000 hr on stream by using the In2O3/ ZrO2 catalyst [14]. In other words, the In2O3-based catalyst has the prospects for industrial deployment in synthesising methanol from CO2 hydrogenation. However, fundamental aspects of CO2 hydrogenation over the In2O3 catalyst, such as the reaction mechanism and kinetics, have not been investigated in-depth [13]. To investigate the performance of In2O3-based catalyst on the synthesis of methanol via CO2 hydrogenation, a detailed kinetic model and information on its kinetics are required. Over the years, the reaction pathway towards methanol using a Cu-based catalyst has been thoroughly discussed due to Cu's high intrinsic activity [7]. Hence, several kinetic models have been derived with varying underlying physical mechanisms. The most frequently used kinetic models are from Graaf et al. [15] and Vanden et al. [16]. Other models have been developed by Seidel et al. [17], Ma et al. [18], and Villa et al. [19]. These models were used to predict the feasibility of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on a larger scale. Besides plant modelling, researchers are also interested in finding the most efficient and advanced reactor configuration for methanol production. There are differences between the kinetic models, so the deviation between results can be observable. Indeed, there is no general agreement in the literature about which model is better and should be used [16]. Two categories of kinetic studies can be carried out: lumped kinetics and microkinetics [20]. Lumped kinetics are commonly performed by most studies such as Graaf et al. [15] and Villa et al. [19]. Hence it has been chosen to be the starting point of this work [20]. It utilises a simple kinetic model to represent the overall reaction, and a rate-determining step (rds) was assumed [20]. The study of kinetics in heterogeneous catalysis is crucial in the analysis of mechanistic details and the design of chemical reactors [21]. Hence, this work is designed to fill the gap by proposing a kinetic model for the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst in the reaction of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol that can provide useful information such as reaction rates and activation energies. Unlike other conventional bulk In2O3 catalysts, CeO2 support was added in this study which is more effective in improving the metal dispersion and the formation of oxygen vacancies [22]. Characterisation studies from Martin et al. [14] have pointed out that the oxygen vacancies act as the active sites for methanol synthesis. Bulk In2O3 was reported to have significantly lower activity towards the formation of methanol due to the high surface degree of reduction. By incorporating the effect of support, the number of surface oxygen vacancies could be tuned to improve the catalyst’s activity [23]. CeO2 support was chosen over Zirconia Dioxide (ZrO2) as a comparison was made on the performance between a CeO2 and a ZrO2 supporting Cu-based catalyst where Cu/ CeO2 catalyst resulted in higher methanol selectivity than the one supported on ZrO2 [22]. The structure of CeO2 material, such as the crystal plane, size, and morphology, affect the catalytic activity by providing a suitable surface configuration for the adsorption and activation of CO2 [24]. With the nature of CeO2 material, the reducibility of the support can be improved, and perturbation in the electronic properties of the metal and the metal-oxide interface can occur, leading to synergistic effects [24]. To the best of our knowledge, no studies have been done with the incorporation of CeO2 as a support for the In2O3 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Hence, this work aims to study the catalytic performance of the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst for the synthesis of methanol. It will be performed through an experimental data set covering a wide range of temperatures (200–300 °C), pressure (1–50 bar), and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) (hr−1). Furthermore, a fundamental understanding of the kinetics of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was investigated over an In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst. This paper presents a kinetic model specifically for the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst with the reaction mechanism proposed based on an LHHW dual-site mechanism. Reaction route (RR) analysis was chosen in this methodology to develop the rate expression of nonlinear kinetics as it offers a useful implementation of analysing various reaction schemes [25]. RR analysis was utilised with the presumption of the most abundant reactive intermediate (MARI) and the rate-determining step. The kinetic model developed was validated with the kinetic parameters estimated from an optimisation technique. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst preparation To synthesize the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst, bulk In2O3 was prepared via precipitation of Indium nitrate precursor by calcination in static air. The CeO2 support was prepared using the reported sol-gel method [24]. Firstly, a 200 ml solution of 0.2 M Cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99% purity) in ethanol (Sigma Aldrich, 99.7% purity) was stirred continuously at 300 rpm under room temperature conditions. Then, 200 ml of 0.2 M citric acid (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99% purity) in ethanol was fed dropwise into the previous solution and stirred for 24 hr. The solvent was then evaporated at 80 °C and stirred at 300 rpm. Next, the solution was left to oven-dry for 24 hr at 80 °C. A xerogel formed during this process was calcined at 500 °C in static air for 5 hr with a heating rate of 3 °C/ min. The calcined CeO2 support was then incorporated into the In2O3 using the wetness-impregnation method. In2O3 was added in a measured amount of 0.591 mg accordingly to obtain the loading of 7 wt%. The measured In2O3 was dissolved in 76 ml of ethanol and 24 ml of deionized water and then stirred at room temperature. Next, 2 g of the support material was crushed, added to the solution, and stirred for 4 hr. Lastly, the solvents were evaporated at 40 °C, and the solids were calcined at 300 °C for 3 hr with a heating rate of 3 °C/ min. Hence, the In2O3 (7 wt%)/ CeO2 catalyst was successfully synthesized and used for the further stage of the experiment. 2.2 In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst activity tests To test the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst’s activity, experiments were carried out in a custom-designed stainless-steel high-pressure packed-bed reactor with a tubular flow, as shown in Fig. 1. For each catalytic run, 0.2 g of In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst (7 wt% of In) with a size of 38–45μm were reduced at 300 °C (heating rate 3 °C/ min) and 1 bar pressure for 2 hr under 100 ml STP/ min of H2 (Air Liquide 99.9% purity) flow. Post-reduction, 100 ml STP/ min of 20% CO2 in H2 and 50 ml STP/ min of Argon were fed in, and the reactor was pressurized to 50 bar through a pneumatically controlled back pressure regulator. Then, the temperature, pressure, and space velocity were varied accordingly in every run with the conditions specified in Table 1. The nominal conditions were fixed at the temperature of 300 °C, pressure at 50 bar, space velocity at 17,681.4 hr−1, and feed gas composition with a molar ratio of H2/ CO2 = 4 and Ar as the inert gas. The reaction products were analysed online using Agilent 7890 A GC-TCD/ FID system coupled with HayeSep N, MolSieve 5 A, and Porapak Q columns. The gas was sampled online at intervals of ∼35 min for a period of 5 hr. Subsequently, the catalysts were cooled under 100 ml STP/ min Argon (Air Liquide 99.9%). The carbon balance for the experiments was > 93%. No liquid products were obtained from the study. The effluent collected was calibrated with varying concentrations of CO, CO2, CH3OH, C2H6, DME, and H2O. Subsequently, the molar yields and space-time yield (STY) were calculated as stated in the Supplementary Information (SI). The heat and mass transfer limitations were checked using the Weisz-Prater criterion ( ≪ 3 ), the Damkholer number ( ≪ 1 ), and the Anderson criterion [26–28]. These criteria were satisfied for all experimental conditions applied, in which the details are shown in Section S2. The experimental results were illustrated in plots of methanol STY against time at different operating conditions, as provided in Fig. S1- Fig. S3. As shown in Fig. S1- Fig. S3, the methanol STY increases steeply at the initial hour and gradually becomes stagnant, resulting in an “exponential rise” shaped curve. To best fit the series of data points, the exponential curve fitting was used with an asymptotic curve equation as the general model. Coefficients for the exponential model with > 95% confidence bounds were generated from the best fit curve. To investigate the steady-state kinetics for the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst, a steady-state point was chosen out of an average of 10 points of data collected for each experimental run. For all the experimental data sets, the methanol STY at the reaction time of 3 hr was chosen as the steady-state point. The effluents’ compositions were mostly stable after the reaction time of 3 hr. In total, there were 13 steady-state points selected for each operating condition. Table S1 overviews the chosen steady-state points with their respective methanol STY and reaction conditions. 3 Model development 3.1 Kinetic model development The kinetic model derived for the In2O3 catalyst was based on a dual-site LHHW. There are a total of two sites (S1 and S2) available for the adsorption of H2 and CO2, where site S1 represents In2O3 centres for H2 adsorption, and site S2 represents sites for CO2 adsorption, which are predominantly oxygen vacancies of In2O3 in CeO2. As a result, the site balance is depicted as the following: (4) S 1 total = S 1 + H 2 ∙ S 1 (5) S 2 total = S 2 + CO 2 ∙ S 2 The site balance developed was assumed to vary according to process conditions such as space velocity influencing selectivity due to RWGS activity. The assumption made for all 9 elementary step reactions in the kinetic model was that all the CO2 adsorption sites present on either In2O3 or CeO2 are identical. Besides, In2O3 does not inherently contain oxygen vacancies. They are only created in the presence of H2 [13]. 3.2 Reaction route analysis There are seven elementary steps for the formation of methanol from CO2, whereas there are two steps for the RWGS. To determine the overall rate equation, RR analysis was utilized to determine which elementary step is the rate-determining. The elementary step with the highest resistance is the rds in the reaction pathway. The reaction mechanism was calculated according to Ohm’s law concept applied to an electric circuit [25]. The step resistance is the inverse of a forward rate of a specific elementary reaction, and it was estimated using the LHHW approach [25]. The rate expressions for each elementary reaction can be found in Table S2. The assumption made during calculation was that one of the elementary steps was a rds and all other steps were in partial equilibrium [25]. Finally, the overall rate equation representing the process was developed based on the rds for the methanol synthesis reaction. 3.3 Most abundant reaction intermediate (MARI) analysis To further simplify the rate expressions, MARI analysis was performed using the analytical expression developed for individual surface species on the metallic and adsorption sites. Two equations were constructed for the intermediates adsorbed species on two different active sites (S1 for H2 adsorption site and S2 for the CO2 site). The reaction intermediates with the highest surface coverage and the adsorption sites were included in the rate expressions, indicating that they are strongly adsorbing on the catalyst’s surface compared to the other intermediates. Hence, reducing the rate expressions for the coverages to MARI intermediates. 3.4 Kinetic parameters estimation The calculation for the kinetic parameters for RR analysis, MARI analysis and parameter optimisation was performed using values sourced from the literature [13]. Arrhenius equation was used to calculate kinetic rate constants, k in the adsorption and desorption reactions, as shown in Section S6. However, the calculation for the k value for the surface reaction has considered an additional parameter: the site density, θ of the adsorbed H2 and adsorbed CO2 that took place. The site densities of the adsorbed reactants obtained from the measurements were calculated using Eq. (S13). The reparametrized Arrhenius equation used for calculating the surface kinetic rate constants was below Eq. (6). (6) k = A ∙ θ i exp ( − Ea RT ) Where A represents the pre-exponential factor (s−1), θi is the site density for i = site S1 or site S2 (mol/kg.cat) and Ea= activation energy, J/mol. The A value was derived from the order of magnitude based on TST where the surface and desorption reaction were assumed to be average of 101-1013, 1013-1016 s−1, respectively as suggested for a typical pseudo-first-order pre-exponential factors for various rate-limiting steps [20]. As for the pre-exponential factor value for the adsorption reaction, the value is suggested to be 106 atm s−1 [29]. Herein, an In2O3 (111) site’s Gibbs free energy profile (Reaction conditions at 50 bar and 300 °C) for the hydrogenation of CO2 was utilized to determine the activation energies and equilibrium constant for each reaction pathway [13]. Since the thermodynamic equilibrium constant for the methanol synthesis reaction is only temperature-dependent, the equation provided in the work of Graaf et al. was directly used [30]. The equilibrium adsorption constant for H2 and CO2 was also computed using the adsorption and desorption kinetic rate constants suggested for gas-phase species [20]. An objective function is minimised by optimising the kinetic parameters with constraints set to estimate the kinetic parameters. In this work, MATLAB R2021a software was employed to solve the objective function globally in the means of validating the kinetic model. The objective function to be minimised was as depicted in Eq. (7), based on the relative error sum of squares in which the parameter fitting is applied only for methanol synthesis reaction. (7) O . F = ∑ i = 1 N ( r im − r ic ) 2 Where r im is the modelled reaction rate (mol/s/kgcat), r ic is the experimental reaction rate (mol/s/kgcat) and subscript i represents the number of experimental runs. The experimental reaction rates for methanol can be easily determined from simple mixed-flow material balances over the reactor. The formula used to calculate the experimental rate was obtained from Graaf et al. [15] as shown in Eq. (S10) and Eq. (S11). The total pressure and temperature in the equations correspond to the conditions at which the gas flow rate was being measured (room temperature and atmospheric pressure). For the optimisation techniques, methods based on numerical optimisation were applied using MATLAB’s Global optimisation toolbox. The calculated kinetic parameters as mentioned above and the pre-exponential factors obtained from the literature [20,29] were used as the initial point of estimation. Constraints were specified as the lower and upper bounds of the estimated variables, as shown in Table S3. In total, the estimation was conducted for 15 kinetic parameters which included 3 A (surface, adsorption and desorption), 5 Ea, and 7 ∆ G ° values. These optimised results were reported in Table S3. 4 Results and discussions 4.1 Experimental catalytic activity of In2O3/CeO2 catalyst Eq. (1) is an exothermic reaction and thermodynamically less favourable when temperature increases, leading to lesser methanol formed. In contrast, the rise in temperature will favour the competing RWGS reaction, which is endothermic. CO and H2O are expected to form as by-products instead of methanol which will lower the selectivity of methanol. However, this trend was not observed in the experimental results (Table 1) with no CO formation at a temperature of 300 ̊C. The In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst used in this work has shown high selectivity toward methanol production. This result was further confirmed at varying pressure and space velocity conditions at the temperature of 300 ̊C with no formation of CO detected except for Exp S1 & S2. For In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst, the optimum reaction temperature was found to be 250 ̊C with the highest conversion of CO2 at 77%. The further increase in temperature was observed to decrease the conversion of CO2 to methanol. At higher GHSV conditions, high methanol selectivity (above 90%) was observed as shown in Exp S3 and S4. RWGS reaction was observed to be limited at higher GHSV values, which were also reported in the work of Rui et al. [31]. According to Le Chatelier’s principle, increasing the pressure should shift the equilibrium towards the right with fewer molecules. The formation of methanol is expected to increase as pressure increases. However, from the experimental results, the conversion of CO2 to methanol and methanol selectivity showed opposite trends. This might be due to the formation of methane which is also a possible reaction from the hydrogenation of CO2 [32]. According to Wang et al. [33], the trend observed for the In2O3-based catalysts was that lower CO2 conversions generally accompany high methanol selectivity whereas high CO2 conversions can be obtained at a lower methanol selectivity. This observation can be explained by the possible increase in the formation of H2O when the conversion of CO2 is high. When the amount of H2O increases, the In2O3-based catalyst is more susceptible to sintering, leading to the destruction of oxygen vacancies and hence, lowering the production of methanol [33]. Future work such as steam and CO co-feeding could be done to test the effect of adding these substances. The experimental reaction rates for methanol and H2O can be easily determined using Eq. (S10) and Eq. (S11) . These observed rates were further used for kinetic modelling with the effect of reaction conditions discussed in Section 4.3. 4.2 Kinetic model Table 3 shows the elementary step derived for the direct hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol using an In2O3-based catalyst. The individual rate expressions for each elementary reaction are derived based on the assumption that all steps are the rate-determining steps. R1-R7 represent the methanol formation reaction, whereas R8-R9 are the RWGS reactions. In this study, the reaction mechanism was based on a dual-site LHHW mechanism. Hence there were two adsorptive sites (S1 and S2). S1 denotes for H2 adsorption site whereas S2 denotes for CO2 adsorption site. Table 2 in the following shows the reaction mechanism for the active sites on the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst, which are responsible for H2 and CO2 adsorption. The equation for the intermediates adsorbed species derived from the site balance can be written in terms of the equilibrium constants (KB1 and KB2 represent the adsorption equilibrium constant for H2 and CO2 respectively), (KR1-R7 represent the equilibrium constant of elementary reactions R1 to R7), and partial pressures of the gaseous products (Pi with subscript i representing different gaseous species). (8) C S 1 = 1 1 + K B 1 P H 2 + P C H 3 OH K R 7 K B 1 P H 2 ( 1 + 1 K R 6 K B 1 P H 2 ) (9) C S 2 = 1 1 + K B 2 P CO 2 K B 1 P H 2 ( 1 K B 1 P H 2 + K R 1 + K R 1 K R 2 K B 1 P H 2 + K R 3 K R 2 K R 1 K B 1 P H 2 + K R 4 K R 3 K R 2 K R 1 K B 1 P H 2 3 2 + K R 8 ) Each elementary reaction for the methanol formation was expressed into individual rate equations as shown in Table S2. The RR analysis was carried out by computing each step resistance with the value of CS1, Eq. (8) and CS2, Eq. (9) substituted and inversed the rate expressions. Note that the values of the equilibrium constants and partial pressure were substituted according to the experimental range of temperature. Hence, the step resistances were plotted as a function of temperature. As seen in Fig. 2., the highest resistance was dominated by R5 as compared to other elementary steps. The step with the highest resistance is known as the slowest step, hence the rds [34]. Thus, the overall rate expression for the synthesis of methanol over the supported In2O3 catalyst was derived from the rds (R5). MARI analysis was subsequently carried out to develop a simplified rate expression from R5. Also, it was used to study the effect of the reaction intermediates on the rate expression. The analysis includes the calculation of the surface coverage fraction for each intermediate species, including the 2 adsorption sites. The result of the analysis was displayed in Fig. 3. and Fig. 4. which shows the surface coverage of the most abundant surface intermediates at two separate adsorption sites as a function of temperature from 200° to 300°C. By comparing the coverage fraction, the H* intermediate was mostly found on the adsorption site S1 whereas the formate (CHO2 *) and CO2 * were mostly found on the adsorption site S2. These findings were consistent with other reported results where the surface-bound formate CHO2 was determined as one of the key reaction intermediates [35]. It also revealed that there was no effect of the temperature on the surface coverage of H* and CHO2 * whereas the coverage of CO2 * increases with an increase in temperature. Hence, the final rate expression was reduced to Eq. (10) as follows: (10) r MeOH = k R 5 K R 4 K R 3 K R 2 K R 1 K B 1 P H 2 2 1 + K B 1 P H 2 K B 2 P C O 2 ( 1 + K B 1 P H 2 ) 1 + K B 2 P C O 2 + K R 1 K B 1 P H 2 P C O 2 K B 2 − P C H 3 OH P H 2 O K K B 1 P H 2 3 This was also used as the modelled rate expression for the kinetic parameter estimation. 4.3 Kinetic parameters estimation and validation of the kinetic model Fig. 5, Fig. 6, and Fig. 7 show the applicability of the kinetic model for In2O3/ CeO2 at varying pressure, temperature, and space velocity operating conditions. These results can be further explained by the dependence of the methanol synthesis rate on the varying experimental condition that was exhibited in the simulation’s results. This was evident from the trend of the simulated rates whereby the effects of the operating condition agreed with the thermodynamics of the reaction. To investigate the effect of temperature on methanol synthesis rate, the reaction temperature varied between 200 °C and 300 °C. The increase in temperature will lead to an increase in the rate of methanol production due to the increased chances of successful collisions for the gas molecules. The effect of temperature on the reaction rate is directly influenced by the way of the Arrhenius law. This can be observed from the increased synthesis rate of methanol for both experimental and modelling. However, when the temperature increases, the endothermic RWGS was also promoted. Hence, the reaction rate of CO2 hydrogenation should slow down as the temperature rises due to the competitive RWGS reaction. The total pressure during the experiment varied between 1 bar and 50 bar. Thermodynamically, pressure increase leads to an increase in the production of methanol at equilibrium whereas pressure does not affect the RWGS reaction. This was evident from the positive upward curve in the fitted trendline. An increase in pressure implies more collisions of gaseous molecules can occur, hence increasing the chance for the adsorption of reactants on the catalyst, which leads to increased reactant consumption and conversion to methanol. Thus, the modelled methanol synthesis rates agreed with the increasing trend when pressure increases. The GHSV varied between 5,893 hr−1 and 58,938 hr−1. This parameter can be described as an inverse quantity of space-time or as a non-dimensional velocity [36]. Thus, an increase in the GHSV will result in a decrease in the residence time. The effect can be seen in Fig. 7 with the increasing trend of synthesis rates when GHSV increases as more reactants were being fed into the reactor. By using the methanol synthesis rate expression derived for the catalyst, the validation of the kinetic model was carried out by comparing the simulated methanol synthesis rate versus experimentally calculated rates. As shown in the parity plot in Fig. 8, the rate expression developed with the estimated kinetic parameters suggested in Table 4 has resulted in a methanol synthesis rate with reasonable accuracy. The R-squared value calculated for the modelling was 93%. In other words, the kinetic model developed for In2O3/ CeO2 using the RR analysis was robust. Since the parameter fitting was conducted using the reduced rate expression, the accuracy of the results suggested that the MARI analysis was valid. On the other hand, the proposed kinetic parameters estimated were consistent across the range of operating conditions. The complete list of the estimated parameter values can be found in Table S3. This can be observed from the A value for the surface reaction which has the same order of magnitude across the different conditions. Similarly, the Ea value of the surface reaction and other estimated parameters were in a similar order of magnitude with a maximum of 30% discrepancy. Hence, it can be concluded that the consistency of the kinetic parameters proposed has validated the accuracy of the model developed. A comparison of the estimated activation energies between the optimisation and values from the literature was summarised in Table 5. Numerical values given in the table are dependent on the used catalyst, the operating conditions, and the H2/ CO2 ratio. The comparison between the kinetic study reported by Frei et al. [13] and, this work shows that the numerical values of Ea were of a different order of magnitude for the methanol synthesis reaction. It is because this work was using an In2O3 catalyst with CeO2 support, whereas Frei et al.’s work used a bulk In2O3 catalyst. Pure oxide catalyst should have higher Ea required than a supported catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, whereas the RWGS reaction is equivalent [37]. This is evident from the activation energy of the In2O3/ ZrO2 catalyst reported by the work of Chou et al. [38]. A supported catalyst achieves a better dispersion of active sites that leads to more oxygen vacancies being created, providing a higher chance of successful collision with the reactants. This is induced by the hydrogen spillover mechanism which involves the surface migration of activated hydrogen atoms from the metal catalyst particle onto the catalyst support [39]. The reducibility of the supports’ surface plays an important role in determining the efficiency of hydrogen spillover. Catalyst support’s surfaces with high reducibility are proven to have faster spillover occurrence and are not limited by short distances between the catalytic particles [39]. With a highly reducible surface like Ce, the mutual reducibility of metal and the support can be promoted through the spillover mechanism [40]. The formation of additional number of oxygen vacancy sites which act as the active sites can allow more adsorptions of more CO2 molecules, resulting in a lower activation energy for CO2 adsorption. Hence, this explains the low activation energy obtained for In2O3/ CeO2 as compared to other reported values as provided in Table 5. Furthermore, the activation energy obtained from the kinetic modelling of this work is consistent (same magnitude order) with the experimental results using the Arrhenius plot shown in Fig. 9. It can be concluded that the kinetic parameters estimated are feasible. On the other hand, the estimated activation energy of CeO2 supported In2O3 catalyst has resulted in lower activation energy for the surface reaction to occur. This is in line with the previous statement made that the CeO2 support on the Cu-based catalyst had a higher methanol selectivity than the one supported on ZrO2. The lower activation energy required for CeO2 supported catalyst implies that most of the CO2 will react with H2 to form methanol instead of CO due to the competing RWGS reaction with higher apparent activation energy for the reaction [35]. With the same energy applied, more methanol could be produced via In2O3/ CeO2 indicating higher methanol selectivity. 5 Conclusion Methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation using In2O3 (7 wt%)/ CeO2 catalyst was investigated in this study. The catalytic performance was studied from a set of experimental results with the pressure, temperature and space velocity effects tested under a nominal operating condition at 50 bar, 300 °C, space velocity at 17,681.4 hr−1, and a molar ratio of H2/ CO2 = 4 as the feed gas composition. The limitations of heat and mass transfer were also validated with the Weisz-Prater criterion, the Damkholer number, and the Anderson criterion. These experimental results have been followed by a kinetic modelling procedure under steady-state conditions. A kinetic model has been proposed considering 7 elementary step reactions for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The RR analysis was utilised and the formation of formaldehyde (HCHO) was identified as the rds. A methanol synthesis rate expression based on a dual-site LHHW mechanism was constructed and simplified using the MARI analysis. Besides, 15 kinetic parameters were estimated using a constrained optimisation solver to further validate the rate expression. The simplified rate expression for methanol synthesis was shown to be feasible. This was evident from the consistency in the estimated kinetic parameters and the modelled methanol synthesis rate was found to fit the experimental data well. In addition, a comparison of the pre-exponential factor and activation energy for the surface reaction was made with reported values. The lower activation energy displayed from the simulated results has proven the CeO2 support on In2O3 catalyst to be a more effective catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation. Although the kinetic model was shown to be consistent with the experimental data under different reaction conditions, there are still limitations in this work that could further improve the kinetic studies and apply them for process and reactor design. Firstly, the DFT simulation’s microkinetics data obtained from the literature was based on a pure In2O3 material. However, in this work, CeO2 has been incorporated as the support with only 7 wt% of In2O3 in the catalyst system. The DFT simulation results may differ since the addition of ceria as the support causing the change in the catalyst’s structure was not considered in the calculations. Further, the kinetic modelling study over In2O3/ CeO2 should be investigated by incorporating the effect of CO in the feed gas. This is to consider the composition of the captured CO2 (presence of at least 30% CO) as a syngas source in the industrial. Besides, the effect of the reacting conditions on the competitive RWGS reactions was not investigated. Rate expression for RWGS reaction can be developed to compare against the methanol synthesis reaction to further investigate the thermodynamic coupling of both reactions. In conclusion, the developed kinetic model for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol using the In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst was well fitted with the experimental data with a set of kinetic parameters optimised that can be applied for reactor modelling in the future for scaling up purposes. coredata.dc:description: This work investigates the kinetics of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst based on a dual-site Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. Such studies on reaction kinetics and mechanism using In2O3 catalyst, which possesses high activity, selectivity and stability are limited. Thirteen sets of experimental data at steady-state using In2O3/ CeO2 catalyst with varying temperature (200–300 °C), pressure (1–50 bars), gas hourly space velocity (5,893 hr−1 −58,938 hr−1) were analysed. The experimental data were modelled to determine the rate-determining step and the rate expression using the Most-Abundant Reaction Intermediate (MARI) analysis. The reaction mechanism for this catalyst was proposed based on a reported DFT study on In2O3. An optimisation procedure was performed to identify new kinetic parameters using MATLAB-based code with nonlinear regression analysis. A comparison of estimated kinetic parameters was made with reported values. The derived kinetic model can be applied for reactor modelling in the future for scaling up purposes.
coredata.dc:title: Experimental work and kinetic modelling of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on CeO2 supported In2O3 catalyst
